captions.text:
That's a very
grave charge, son.

Are you aware that it's unlawful
to practice medicine without
a medical license ?
Yes, sir, l am.

Are you aware that running a medical
clinic without the proper licensing...

can place both you
and the public...
in a great deal of danger ?
ls a home a clinic, sir ?

lf you are admitting patients
and treating them...

physical location
is irrelevant.

Sir, will you define
treatment for me ?

Yes. Treatment would be defined
as the care of a patient
seeking medical attention.

Have you been treating patients,
Mr. Adams ?

l live with several people.
They come and go as they please.

l offer them
whatever help l can.
Mr. Adams...

have you or have you not
been treating patients at your ranch ?

Everyone who comes to the ranch
is a patient, yes.
[ Murmuring ]

And every person who comes
to the ranch is also a doctor.
l'm sorry ?

Every person who comes
to the ranch is in need...

of some form of physical
or mental help.
They're patients.

But also every person who comes
to the ranch is in charge of
taking care of someone else--

whether it's cooking for them,
cleaning them...

or even as simple a task
as listening.
That makes them doctors.

l use that term broadly, but is not a
doctor someone who helps someone else ?

When did the term ''doctor'' get
treated with such reverence, as,
''Right this way, Doctor Smith''...

or, ''Excuse me, Dr. Scholl
what wonderful footpads''...

or, ''Pardon me, Dr. Patterson,
but your flatulence has no odor'' ?
[ Laughing, Murmuring ]

At what point in history
did a doctor become more...

than a trusted and learned friend
who visited and treated the ill ?

Now, you ask me if
l've been practicing medicine.

Well, if this means opening
your door to those in need--
those in pain--

caring for them, listening
to them, applying a cold cloth
until a fever breaks--

if this is practicing medicine,
if this is treating a patient...

then l am guilty
as charged, sir.

Did you consider the ramifications
of your actions ?

What if one of your patients
had died ?

What's wrong
with death, sir ?

What are we so mortally
afraid of ?

Why can't we treat death with
a certain amount of humanity
and dignity and decency...

and, God forbid,
maybe even humor ?

Death is not the enemy,
gentlemen.

lf we're gonna fight a disease,
Iet's fight one of the most
terrible diseases of all--
indifference.

Now, l've sat in your schools and heard
people lecture on transference...
and professional distance.

Transference
is inevitable, sir.

Every human being
has an impact on another.

Why don't we want that in
a patientldoctor relationship ?

That's why l've listened to your
teachings, and l believe they're wrong.

A doctor's mission should be
not just to prevent death...

but also to improve
the quality of life.

That's why you treat a disease,
you win, you lose.

You treat a person, l guarantee you,
you win, no matter what the outcome.

title: Patch Adams (8/10) Movie CLIP - You Treat a Person (1998) HD

comments.text:
If your only exposure to Patch Adams was this movie, please visit take a 
moment to listen to the real doctor speak.  He wasn't crazy like the 
Hollywood character in this movie.﻿
comments.author: Holo Wolf

comments.text:
Transference is a phenomenon characterized by unconscious redirection of 
feelings from one person to another. One definition of transference is "the 
inappropriate repetition in the present of a relationship that was 
important in a person's childhood."

So sorry- I do not want to be abused by phony doctors in terms of receiving 
transference.  Oh wait- movie scripts are written by dim wits, made for 
people even more dim-witted.  

Transference can be a desirable trait in hate mongering activities, and 
activities that go against the civil liberties of any group or individual.

Sorry Jesus.﻿
comments.author: Jay Flippen

comments.text:
+Jay Flippen You do realize the other definition of the word is simply "the 
process of transferring something"? The psychoanalytical definition is used 
when talking about a patients behavior, not the simple fact that things 
impact other things, including humans.

comments.author: Logan

comments.text: +Logan  thank you for being able to accept someone else's different opinion.
comments.author: meritmthl

comments.text:
+meritmthl It was based on a real doctor, Hunter Adams that had a vision of 
a different style of healthcare and created Gesundheit! Institute in 1971.  
Not only does the movie show how an unorthodox approach on treating 
patients, but also the appreciation of death through humor. It shows how a 
man who persevered despite losing his mind and his love because he believed 
in a bigger cause. 

I guess I enjoyed it more because it grabbed me into the emotional 
rollercoaster of laughs, anger, sadness, depression, and empathy.  
I loved it just like his other underrated movie, What Dreams May Come.
comments.author: The Truth

comments.text: Thanks for the explanation
comments.author: Logan

comments.text:
+Logan I saw the movie back in 98 when it first came out and didn't like 
it.  I then read some of the reviews, and all were bad.  For a humorous 
explanation on why many people don't like it, you may want to check out 
Nostalgia Critics review of it.  In short,  the movie is too syrupy and 
cliched.  Not one of Robin William's better works in my opinion...but too 
each their own.

comments.text:
I was raised In a small town called Woodfin,Theres a place In this movie 
where Robin was at a bus stop,It was right above my house,I also have spent 
a lot of my younger day's In the very spot where the butterfly land's on 
his heart In the movie,That happened on Buzzard Rock.I feel kinda special 
just to know that because of Robin Williams as Patch Adams my home and my 
old hang out was graced by his presence.Thank's for stopping by 
Mr.Williams/Patch.You made my hometown and my old party place a lot more 
special just by being there.Rest In the most happy place In the universe 
and thanks for all you done.Sincerely,Mark D. Woodfin,N.C.﻿

 "Whats wrong with death sir? Why are we so morally afraid of death? Why 
can't we treat death with humanity and dignity and decency and god forbid

comments.author: Ariel Jones

comments.text:
I still can't believe that two actors in this film has died in this year 
months apart. Phillip Seymour  Hoffman died of a drug overdose and Robin 
Williams died of a suicide. I just want to say yes we all have or had 
problems in life and will have more problems in the future but we have to 
come out with our problems to our loved ones and those you hardly know and 
they will offer support. even though they don't know what we're going 
though they will help us out and we shouldn't end our life to soon. life is 
like a candle and we shouldn't blow it out before our time because we mean 
so much to our loved ones and also to those we hardly know. everyone just 
look at the positive things of life and not the negative trust me I thought 
of suicide but I'm still alive for those that I love and those I hardly 
know. treasure your life please. Robin Williams and  Phillip Seymour 
Hoffman R.I.P.﻿
